intro: Haplopappus serrulatus, commonly known as the prairie sandwort, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cress plants. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open habitats such as prairies and disturbed areas. It produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in early spring, followed by small, dry fruits called siliques. Haplopappus serrulatus is generally low-growing, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves.
